comments.commentBody: @Judge Bean: Please enlighten us as to how Hillary's credentials (or, for that matter, her abilities) best the Vice President's.
What impact will this have on society, vs, what productivity society will gain drilling for and burning fossil fuels? Jesus, I see a conflict of cause! Help me out here!

Bravo! If Ohio wants to continue to honor President McKinley, it is free to do so, but Alaskans should be able to determine what places in their own state are called, and frankly, it is high time that the appropriateness of some naming choices is reassessed. Several institutional buildings here in North Carolina have recently been renamed as racist attitudes, well beyond the norm for even their own time, of some of the past honorees have come to light.

Quite a plunger, this guy.

We're home. We saw "Antony and Cleopatra" in Ashland, Oregon last night. It was a wonderful experience in their open-air theater under the stars. It was a very odd production, as is their wont, but not unsuccessful. Let's just say playing them like Kanye and Kim is justifiable.

Tomorrow I have to deposit the water company receipts and get out the August bills, so I'll probably not have too much time to catch up here. Glad to be home.

Every single American dollar in existence was created by the United States government.  When the Fed wants to lower interest rates, it creates additional dollars and uses them to buy treasury notes or other financial instruments.  So William Cohan's assertion that the quantity of dollars in existence shouldn't be decided "by a market behemoth" (i.e. the Federal Government) makes as much sense the demand to "keep your government hands off my Medicare."
@Phil: So why does The Times provide employment to professional Hillary-hater Maureen Dowd?

I had to crack up at my boyfriend's reaction after I made it for him.  He graciously ate 2 helpings and then when I asked for an honest review (bc I had mixed feelings about it) he said, "well, it's kinda like....eating insulation."  But he reassured me "if it were served in prison, prisoners would likely be coming up for 2nd and 3rds."  I appreciated his honesty!  It was a one-time make for me!
URDU is all I have ever seen.  Maybe you saw it misspelled!
Quite likely, MOL, although I seem to remember it spelled that way in a crossword.

Erdu has never appeared in a Times crossword.

Verdun.

Zipped through this invitation to go swimming. Erdu before URDU. GUN works better for revving an engine, unless you have a battery powered car like the Tesla S we saw today in Oregon. Then gen would work better and Erdu could be spelled properly.
The US exported its hazardous industries to China, which was willing to take it on for the sake of development.

There's an old expression that goes something like this:
"Point a finger at someone, and three others on your hand point back to you".

I'm Canadian, and together with the U.S. we as "new world" countries have no right to chastise anyone else. We have polluted and destroyed vast parts of North America in the pursuit of wealth andy material gains.

Every week, one can easily find some sort of pollution incident, train derailment, a banded mine recurrence of pollution, and so on and so forth.

So before we point the finger at someone else, let's refer to that old biblical phrase (I'm not religious but like the phrase):

"Let he who is without sin cast the first stone."
Never heard of Erdu.  Is it what Pakistanis speak when they park near the kerb?

I don't know what you mean about the saltiness of the corn kernels, but, regarding the chewiness, some corn kernels may have tougher "skins" on them, especially if older and not as sweet. What I would do is strain the pureed corn and milk mixture through a fine sieve to remove the chewy fiber of tougher corn. That would produce a smoother texture with all the flavor of the corn.
"than No Escape, which I've also seen" and was granted the courtesy of a Times review.

Its artistic quality (or lack of same) notwithstanding it's genuinely absurd that The Times didn't even bother reviewing "War Room."  A few months back it was announced that the paper would no longer commit itself to reviewing every movie that opened in NYC (despite the fact that it retains approximately a dozen film critics on its staff).  As a consequence, such movies as "The Young and Prodigious T. S. Spivet" (Jean-Pierre Jeunet), "Dark Places" (Charlize Theron) and "Paulette" (Bernadette Lafont) have come and gone without comment from the Times review staff.  I saw the first two and didn't care for either but the fact remains that they represent the expenditure of time and effort by serious filmmakers and are at least deserving of something more than complete indifference from the country's paper of record.  In any case, they were certainly no worse than "No Escape," which I've also seen.
LizB, I believe that kerfluffle was aimed at a guest blogger while Deb was away. We quickly set him straight. Deb has always adhered to the clue-only principle.

.
.
Kiki, I gladly defer to your numbers. I am unable to count above 5 now that the website keeps track of how many consec. puzzles I solve, whether I want it too or not.

Besides, I confuse easily. Right now, I'm trying to figure out why Dr. Robi's current wife is using lowercase: The Sunday grid had ELKE and today we have ELLE. Seems to be an invitation to use ELKE all week!

After that, I have to figure out the order of this thread ...

Just one more thing to say. This entire argument is an attempt to sway the popular vote a different way. It is born of the idea that most people don't understand the political situation. This is a correct assumption.

However, not understanding the political situation is part of democracy. Most people never will understand the political situation in its reality. The part that I didn't understand was that the economic lies were asymmetric after the crash.

Before the crash? How do you weigh the president against congress? Was Bill Clinton wrong? Horribly wrong. Was the Republican congress wrong? Horribly wrong.

Does that form symmetry? In our flawed political system, to most people, I think it does.

So our major problem might be constitutional structure. Certainly money is now a constitutional problem.

Is the country in a state where a constitutional convention could solve our problems? No way. So we just have to sit put, certainly do what we feel we can, but wait…

For what? Nobody knows.

There's a few of us techies that have listened. I'm not a Richy Rich silicon valley type, but I'm a techie, and the Richy Rich part is not orthogonal to myself.

Why do more not listen? We're just totally flawed as humans. This is not unique to techies, it is a part of the human condition. We generally want to agree with those around us. It's just the way we're built. Some of us hate agreeing, but it isn't really a natural, emotional response, it is a response born of necessity and unique identity.

Everyone wants to fit in and feel comfortable in their surroundings. Once people start getting rich from their intelligence, they start feeling just a bit better that others. There is also work involved, so it becomes easy to justify the feeling.

I believe our hope for silicon valley lies with people like Elon Musk, who have seen the worse of humanity. There are others like him. He's smart, moralistic, and he'll get it too if he can avoid the temptation to feel comfortable among peers. This guy has few peers, but the ones he has are important and influential.

Most of the initial success stories in SV were born of business tactics, a ruthlessness rare among techies. That is changing to some degree.

But there's a new problem in that some of the most recent success stories are about unwise kids. It isn't their fault, but wisdom doesn't come from success or riches. It comes from rich, tough experiences.
I guess. I've seen it spelled both ways. Not sure which is right.
I still don't get how the clue fits the answer, after all the discussion above.

Does that form symmetry? In our flawed political system, to most people, I think it does.

So our major problem might be constitutional structure. Certainly money is now a constitutional problem.

Is the country in a state where a constitutional convention could solve our problems? No way. So we just have to sit put, certainly do what we feel we can, but wait…

For what? Nobody knows.

Can you really claim that QE had NO effect on LT interest rates? See http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/30/upshot/quantitative-easing-is-about-to.... As PK himself has stated, "The hope [of QE] has been that such purchases will drive down the cost of borrowing, and boost the economy even though conventional monetary policy has reached its limit." See http://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/17/opinion/krugman-hating-on-ben-bernanke.... What is the "cost of borrowing" if not interest rates? And if QE had no effect on interest rates, why did PK argue against ending QE? See http://www.pbs.org/newshour/making-sense/paul-krugman-thinks-inflation-f.... QE was not ineffective in lowering interest rates but in stimulating the economy, for which low interest rates had limited stimulative effect (like pushing on a string).

Andrew, your assertion that "the reason to have QE is to encourage banks and such to make loans to business instead of parking their cash in T bills" overlooks the fact that the MANNER by which QE was intended to have such effect was to lower long term interest rates.  QE could not possibly have any direct effect on lending by banks.  After all, banks can't lend without borrowers able and willing to borrow.  Thus, QE was intended to induce borrowers to borrow more by reducing the interest they would have to pay. QE succeeded in reducing long-term interest rates (see my other post for the cite), but had limited effect on stimulating the economy because inadequate aggregate demand, job insecurity and the overhang of heavy debt made many potential borrowers unwilling to borrow despite the low rates resulting from QE.

@Nick Price
You're forgetting the context within which QE occurred, an economy of too little demand and too tight credit. The economy was in danger of losing liquidity. Without QE, the cost of credit would've been higher and demand even lower with obvious negative consequences for economy (not to mention employment). Obviously, QE has its limits, after all, its happening at the ZLB, itself a most unusual circumstance and it was a last resort by the Fed, thanks to an AWOL congress, that decided politics and theology was more important than the welfare of the nation.

I think PK sets up and knocks down a straw man, as his assertion that Cohan erred by seeming to endorse "the old notion of loanable funds" does not refute Cohan's basic points.  I read the Cohan excerpt quoted by PK as basically saying that (i) QE by the Fed has caused long-term interest rates to be artificially low, in the sense of being lower than they would have been in the absence of QE, i.e., if they were determined solely by market forces, and (ii) "manipulating" long term rates in this manner "caused a widespread mispricing of risk," which could have adverse consequences for the economy.  I think point (i) is irrefutable.  If QE did not cause long-term rates to be lower than they otherwise would have been. why have QE at all? On point (ii), PK is silent, apparently believing that he need not address it because of the low level of inflation.  But low inflation (as measured by the CPI) is not incompatible with mispricing of risk.  As evidence, see the housing bubble, which coincided with relatively modest CPI increases.

Nortonism.

Shouldn't we be asleep? :)
Amen!  It will always be National Airport to me.

A quick clarification:  French seams (a special tidy kind of seam) are only interesting if you’re planning to leave the hole open so that you can still turn your scarf inside out.  Otherwise you’d never see them and there’d be no point.  But for a puzzle demo scarf, they're quite nice.

This so called correction does not explain why the stock of a good profitable company with a P/E >18, a yield of 3.5% dividend and an EPS of more than 60% of the dividend was sold, and lost 2% or more.

In 2008 Wells Fargo did not want to cut the dividend, but the FED pressured it into cutting from $0.52 to $0.05 along with some other profitable banks, so that the weak ones would not be obvious. Wells stock fell to the $20 range.

Look at Con Ed and tell my why it was selling last week. The reason for this, is those amateurs that give their money to the fund managers got scared and wanted out, so the funds had to sell for liquidity.

There are some overpriced stocks, mostly boutique stocks, the ones the unsophisticated investor buys because he thinks he is going to make money fast, just like he though he would buying homes at inflated prices.

Just look at the P/E, EPS, and the 90 day moving average. and check the general health of the company. The market fell due to panic, people are the market, this technical mumbo jumbo is for salesmen.

Yes, there is one! :)
http://firstwefeast.com/eat/daniel-boulud-paupiette-of-sea-bass-video/?u...
Any chance there is a you tube demonstration?

I am not a broker or financial adviser so my advice is worth what you are paying for it.

However, there are many good dividend paying stocks to buy. Get a discount brokerage account with a broker like Schwab, they will help with research.
look at socks like Wells Fargo, BB&T, on Ed (ED), Pfizer, Glaxo Smith Klein, Reynolds American, AT&T, and you can average a yield on investment of 3%+, along with capital gains in value.

You can't time the market, it is not a casino, it is a market place of buyers and sellers. Read "The Best Single Investment," and Benjamin Graham's "the Intelligent Investor." Graham is who taught Warren Buffett how to invest. Even at 72, you just have to be patient. Buying and selling quickly just costs you fees and reduces your gain.

Also, and I know I will get flack for this, forget funds. Al you are doing is paying people to buy stocks that pay dividends, they give you some of it. For instance the Con Ed, Black Rock has a bit more than 5%, and so does Vanguard. Just about every major dividend paying stock has large positions owned by some fund. You can buy the same stocks for $8.95 a trade one time, no fees.

$400K should get you about $20K in dividends, and if you have a decent SS you should have about $40K-$45K a year income. if you have to keep working, you can use that to supplement your income from investing.

i think it will be difficult for grownups to forget Adrian's, ah, input, no matter how hard we try. Personally, i'm thinking of oassing it along to a pharmeceutical company for their "Before," pictures files.

Charles,

take note too of the artifacts of civilization, and of forests, emerging whenever northern ice does melt, yes UNDER the ice is where peoples used to live, in fields and forests, then it froze, then as now, it both melts and freezes, as directed by natural forces.
Peoples used to live under the ice, did they?

Cold War, indeed.

But instead of USSR/Russia vs. the West, it appears to be the would-be Defenders of Gaia against anyone attempting to extract resources from the arctic.

One could / should point out that without the mining & petroleum industries, the arctic would be essentially empty of human beings.

One could/should also remind the eco-reporters covering the walrus haul-out that there transport to/from coastal AK was provided by fossil fuels. And, by the way, that walrus haul-outs are well-documented seasonal events which are probably traits of walrus since the beginning of time (and are most likely population-driven, not caused by "loss of sea ice").
